posts.com:
Advice on making a successful advice post on /o/:

If you are looking to get advice on a possible car purchase or car related problem, be sure to include:

What car or cars you are looking at or as detailed a description of the problem as possible. Include make, model, year, mileage, condition, any know faults, the asking price, and what your budget is!

If people have to ask you for every detail, you aren't going to get many replies!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
1.)Get financing ahead of time/know your credit. You always want to have a financing option in hand before you go to a dealership. Nothing wrong with negotiating a better deal with them once you get there, but never go in empty handed. This way you can have idea of how much you can afford to spend, and what a car is going to cost you

2.)Do your research. Know what values KBB/NADA/Edmunds/TrueCar are listing for the cars you are interested in. Also know what other dealerships are listing similar cars for. Dealerships will prey on the uninformed, so make sure that you are

2b.)If you don't know enough about cars to inspect one yourself, arrange to get any used car inspected or bring someone who DOES know what to look for. It's surprisingly easy to polish up a turd and get it passed inexperienced eyes

3.)Never take the first offer, unless it's a place like CarMax that doesn't negotiate. Dealerships know the game, and they always get a certain number of people to bite on the first offer. make them work a little to get your business

4.)You can negotiate on more than the price. Oil changes, services plans, warranties, accessories are all fair game.

5.)In today's world, internet sales departments are your friend. You can send a blanket email to 3 or 4 dealerships and get them to compete for your business, let them haggle with each other before you ever haggle with them

6.)Get them to print you a Buyers Order for any car you are seriously, that is what you negotiate from. It will look like pic related, and itemize every line of the sale. Don't let them 4 square you or hand write shit on a piece of paper. Get a buyers order

7.)Never be afraid to walk away from a deal. If you have a bad feeling, sleep on it. There will always be other cars

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26251148
Should be a good bike. I ride an older small block(small engine architecture, biggest is 850cc, smallest is 350).
Those have the same motor as the older v7, which is similar to my bike.
Breva has a nice brembo brakes, lightweight for a guzzi, good seating position, big tank, and the bigger ones have dual gauges+gas gauge, not sure about the 750.
Top speed is probably 100-120mph, cruise at 4000-5000rpm generally.
Easy maintenaince but drive shaft does mean you get a little more laborious maintenaince less frequently. Just inspecting and greasing splines should be done every tire change or every other change.

They sell cheap because it's not cool like the v7, but not fast enough like the 1000+cc bikes. Great beginner bike or commuter. Should get around 50+mpg.

Forums have great knowledge. If you live in europe should be an easy buy, but here in the states they are more of a DIY/wrencher bike unless you live next to one of the 10-20 dealers....

>>26251369
First bike you will drop because everyone drops their bike either by slipping on gravel at 4mph or by coming to a stop woth the forks not straight. So just accept that you'll probably drop your bike.

Used in good condition from a private sale is the most economical choice. If you have friends that own bikes and know maintenance then rely on them.

Otherwise just get any bike you want. Dual sports tend to have higher seat heights so unless you're a lanket, a shorter bike will be easier to learn on. But you can learn to ride on dual sports so get what interests you.

Take MSF, sit on and test drive bikes, any bike is a good bike, so take the time to explore and choose what you want.

posts.com:
In March 2000, auto sport Magazine of Japan’s front page carried the story that MTCI Racing Team would enter the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM for the upcoming JGTC season, the ultimate “GT1 prototype” racing against the Supras, Skylines, and NSXes. Little is known about the entry apart from Marco Apicella being appointed as the first driver.

However, somewhere along with the negotiations between MTCI and Mercedes-Benz, and perhaps in large part from the shame of the CLR’s massive failure at Le Mans in ‘99, the sale fell through. MTCI Racing Team would instead field a privately-built Porsche Boxster in GT300, with Apicella driving.

By season’s end, MTCI and its race team had collapsed into bankruptcy after the dot-com bubble burst. Chairman Yu Hayakawa was later arrested in 2002 for stock sales fraud. And save for its victory in the 1998 Suzuka 1000km, the Mercedes-Benz CLK-LM never raced in Japan

Moslers actually raced in quite a few national-level GT championships like Grand-Am British, Belgian, Spanish, Australian GT series as well as Grand-Am, several SRO series, and a few rounds in FIA GT as an invite until the homologation rules made it so that a small-scale manufacturer could never be eligible for championship points. The Japanese series would probably see the most of the different variants of the car through the years. It would have the original R, then the GT3 spec, and then the Judd-powered M.

>>26238810
A prototype did compete in 1994. Team Taisan is a stalwart in Japanese motorsports, having formed in 1983 as a privateer team and owned by the Taisan Industrial Company, a global manufacturer of electronic solenoid pumps.

The team enjoyed much racing success throughout the earlier Group A eras with a battery of Nissan R32 GT-Rs, along with BMW M3s in the lower JTCC series.

Business was clearly booming, as the team rocked up to the 1994 season fielding a Ferrari F40 and an ex-Group C Porsche 962 prototype (chassis 962-164). Consider the absurdity: a genuine Le Mans legend rubbing doors with tin-top GT cars. It was an impressive show of force, perfectly encapsulating the excess of Japan’s booming economy and well-heeled motoring enthusiasts. Over five rounds, Taisan’s Porsche 962C and Ferrari F40 won one meeting each, although the championship was ultimately won by Masahiko Kageyama in the Calsonic Hoshino Racing GT-R.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The ‘300ZX-GTS’ in these photos, chassis #009, is a little different than some of the earlier cars. For a start, it’s not twin-turbo V6-powered. Instead, a Nissan VH-series V8 can be found ahead of the quick-change rear end.

Whether it was a spare car or a development car is where things get a little bit murky, but it’s one of only two cars built by Cunningham Racing originally configured for use with the V8 engine, not retrofitted afterwards as other cars were. This would have allowed it to race in the 1995 IMSA GTS-1 class (the VG engine was outlawed at the end of the ’94 season), but the car was reportedly sold to Japan before it competed in any US events In 1997, it had been entered in a couple of JGTC GT500 class races wearing Fedex logos, but did not enjoy any success. Today, in its restored condition, it features the iconic Cunningham Racing 12 Hours of Sebring-winning livery.

The rumble of a V8 in JGTC!

The sound of a roaring V8 and a distinct yellow figure, a sight that in 2002 was a far more familiar sight in the American Le Mans Series, but in that same year, the Autobacs All Japan GT Series had a similar sighting.

Entered by American car tuner ZIPSPEED, the Dunlop clad C4 was of a different breed to its more known Le Mans focused C5.R counterpart. Driven by Toshiyuki Yamamoto and Izumi Yoshida, the C4 struggled against its more suitable rivals, setting a 1:48.146 in its first qualifying session of 2002, in the All Japan GT Championship at Fuji Speedway and failing to qualify for the race while the polesitting #62 Vemac R&D Sport RD320R achieved a 1:32.379.

Four more races were attempted that year, however success never came the team's way, with the C4 making it to qualifying but never having enough speed to make the race.

posts.com:
The JGTC Honda that took on the 24 Hours of Nurburgring!

In 2004, a semi-works Honda programme enlisted a special car to take on the unique challenge that is the Green Hell. The team that year aimed for overall victory and as such acquired a car that could bring them that. That said car was the 2002 GT500 spec Honda NSX. The mid-engine car was already a proven victor in the All Japan Grand Touring Car Championship thanks to the three wins earned by Nakajima Racing, and one each by Mugen and Dome in the 2002 season.

The #3 Honda NSX was entered under the Sport Auto banner and was driven by Armin Hahne, Robert Lechner, Markus Oestreich, and Robin Liddell. A few changes were done to the car to accommodate Nurburgring and the length of the race. One of those changes was the V6 engine being down tuned from the JGTC regulated 500hp to 420hp for reliability. Other changes include endurance lights and Michelin tires of which the car never ran on in the JGTC. The NSX weigh a minimum of 1200kg as par the rules of A6, the class the Honda competed in at Nurburgring.

The #3 Sport Auto NSX had a small amount of kilometres under its belt before contesting the 24 Hours of Nurburgring. Lack of testing however didn't stop the German squad from placing inside the top 15 in qualifying, showing the potential of a JGTC car in uncharted territory. The NSX successfully started the race keeping up with the cars ahead of it which included DTM derived machinery from Audi and Opel. The car however experienced technical problems early in the race and completed 38 laps/7 hours before retiring. https://youtu.be/LRKIAK5Yw3w

posts.com:
>Toyota made history by winning the 2007 Tokashi 24-Hour Race with its Supra HV-R hybrid race car. It is the first time ever that a Hybrid race car has won a competition.

The Supra’s success follows an entry the previous year when Toyota was the first car manufacturer to enter a hybrid vehicle – the Lexus GS450h – into the Tokashi 24-Hour race which finished 17th overall. By entering hybrid systems into racing events, Toyota engineers hope to discover ways to make hybrid systems, most famously fitted to the Toyota Prius production car, more efficient and lighter. In only the second year of competition Toyota used – with success – the data gained from last year’s race in order to develop a new, special racing unit to the limits of hybrid performance.

The race car was based on the iconic Supra GT used in Super GT races in Japan. It was modified and equipped with a special racing hybrid system. In order to improve the system’s energy regeneration and operating efficiency during the race, the following two distinctive technologies have been incorporated into it:

A four-wheel energy regeneration and drive system has been adopted which includes in-wheel motors in the front wheels in addition to one 150 kW rear-axle mounted electric motor. Thanks to this energy regeneration system with three motors/generators, the vehicle can more efficiently recover a greater amount of energy during rapid deceleration and braking from high speeds.

In light of the fact that racing involves a repeated acceleration and deceleration under full system performance, a quick-charging capacitor system was adopted instead of the usual rechargeable batteries.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Every modern McLaren, from the 2011 MP4-12C to the P1 to the 720S is powered by a single family of twin turbo V8s. This engine didn’t come out of nowhere; it started life in a largely-forgotten supercar from Nissan.

This is the Nissan VRH35L. It’s a twin-turbo 3.5 liter aluminum V8 used for endurance racing at Le Mans, the final line of development of Nissan’s VRH35 architecture that debuted in ‘89. Nissan and Tom Walkinshaw Racing (TWR) put the VRH35L together for their entry into the madcap GT1 category back in 1997 in the R390 GT1.

Engine weight was 170 kilos (just over 374 pounds), which I assume counts the weight of the two IHI turbos. Nissan claims its torque figure was “over” 520 lb-ft and horsepower was somewhere around 640 in race trim, 550 for the street-legal homologation specials mandated by the rules.

I do mean specials; only one street R390 GT1 got built, rebodied and VIN-swapped from red to blue, which never made it out of Nissan’s hands.

Nissan was never quite able to eke out a win at Le Mans with the R390 GT1, much as it had never quite been able to get an overall victory in its thousand-horsepower Group C years.

After running in 1997, 1998 and 1999, Nissan peaced out of the 24 Hours of Le Mans’ top classes and the whole effort has fallen into a dusty part of history in a way that, say, Porsche’s 1990s campaigns did not.

But the engine lives on still! Early on in the development of the old MP4-12C, McLaren picked out the VRH35 for the basis of its engine program and bought the rights to it from TWR, as Car and Driver reported at the time. McLaren and their engine builder Ricardo did a great deal of work to the design and basically made the thing their own, renaming it the M838T.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26245054
With the all-new Group C sports car regulations due to be introduced the following year, the 1981 season turned out to be an interim year. The leash on the Group 6 prototypes was already loosened to allow manufacturers to run new engines and/or cars a year early. Porsche used this opportunity to test the engine for the upcoming 956 Group C car in anger during the 24 Hours of Le Mans. One of their privateers, Kremer Racing used the same loophole for Le Mans, not to look ahead but to bring an old legend out of retirement; the Porsche 917.

The Group 6 regulations of 1972, which stipulated a three-litre displacement limit, had rendered the 917 obsolete from World Championship event. In the following decade, Kremer Racing actually restored one of the original 917s for a customer, so they had intimate knowledge of the twelve-cylinder engined racer. The two Kremer brothers reckoned there was life left in the design, especially if it was updated to suit the latest tyre technology. So, instead of bringing one of the existing cars out of retirement, Kremer Racing decided to build a brand new 917, with support from Porsche.

One of the main reasons to start from scratch was that Kremer reckoned the original all-aluminium spaceframe chassis would no longer be up to the task. Already stressed to and at times beyond its limits, the lightweight frame was likely not capable of dealing with the much higher loads produced by 1981-specification, slick tyres. Using the drawings supplied by Porsche and a higher gauge material, a new, sturdier frame was built. The new chassis tipped the scales at 65 kg compared to 50 kg of the original. The suspension geometry was also altered to make the most of the latest tyre technology.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Porsche offered Kremer Racing a choice of two versions of the Type 912 engine. The first was the 4.5-litre unit of the flat-12 that had powered the 917 early in its career and the second was the larger, 5-litre engine fitted to the later developments. While the second option was obviously more powerful, it was also thirstier. Taking into consideration the particular needs of the Le Mans track with its long straights, the Kremers understandably opted for power over frugality. Producing around 600 bhp, the big engine was mated to the tried and trusted five-speed gearbox.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The design and construction of the new 917 K/81 (K was for Kremer this time, not Kurz) took longer than expected, so the aerodynamics had to be rushed. Naturally, the original design of the 917 was carried over but again changes were made to incorporate the latest ideas in aerodynamics. Ideas was the best description as there was no time to actually test the final package in the wind-tunnel. Among the most obvious alterations were the removal of rounded lower sections of the body in favour of slab sides to help generate some ground effect. A full width rear wing was fitted, mounted between two sizeable tail fins.

With backing from French real estate company Malardeau Enterprises and BP, the 917 K/81 was fielded by Kremer Racing for the all-French line-up of Bob Wollek, Xavier Lapeyre and Guy Chausseuil. With the exception of a brief shakedown at the Nürburgring, the car was untested. As a result, it suffered from a variety of problems, in particular on the important long straights where the 917 barely breached the 300 km/h barrier. This was partly addressed by changing the gear ratios but it was also obvious that there were also aerodynamic problems.

With a qualifying time that was a full 17 seconds slower than the pole-sitting works Porsche, the new 917 started the race back in 18th. A steady run saw the car move into the top ten during the opening hours of the race but it then hit a variety of problems. It was finally forced to retire after seven hours following an off that had damaged an oil line, eventually resulting in terminal damage to the engine. By that time, a grief-stricken Bob Wollek had already left the track following the fatal accident of his close friend Jean-Louis Lafosse.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Repaired, Kremer's 917 was brought out once more for the Brands Hatch 1000 km of the World Championship. Shared by Wollek and Henri Pescarolo for the occasion, the car proved better suited to this track and even took the lead briefly. Sadly, it was prompted to retire once more, this time with a suspension failure. This really was the end of the contemporary racing career of the Porsche 917 as the one-off machine was retired and displayed as the centrepiece in the Kremer Racing showroom.

>>26240044
The rally is an off-road endurance event. The terrain that the competitors traverse is much tougher than that used in conventional rallying, and the vehicles used are typically true off-road vehicles and motorcycles, rather than modified on-road vehicles. Most of the competitive special sections are off-road, crossing dunes, mud, camel grass, rocks, and erg among others. The distances of each stage covered vary from short distances up to 800–900 kilometres (500–560 mi) per day. "Amateurs" typically struggle with the event. The rough terrain and lack of skill usually results in accidents and serious injuries.

The Dakar rally features a much greater variety of vehicles than traditional rally's, including bikes, quads, and trucks. Dominant manufacturers within the Dakar Rally are KTM for bikes, Yamaha for quads and Kamaz in trucks. Out of the big three Kamaz are most notable as they have won using the largest variety of vehicles instead of sticking with a select few models. In 2006 a tracked vehicle category was proposed and rejected due to the necessary volume of sub-divisions to ensure fair competition. In 2018 an EV category was proposed, this to was rejected as "there currently exists no electric vehicle capable of crossing the most remote stages of the Dakar unsupported and it would place an unnecessary risk on support crews to enable them to do so", despite annual reviews and counter-claims this continues to be the case. In 2020 Volkswagen proposed an all-electric entry for the 2021 race and although accepted as a non-competing entry, failed to appear.

>>26250656
Not to get on that F150 trend but when I was looking at a truck to tow my trailer I looked at both the F150 and Ranger. I ended up going with an F150 purely because it really wasn't that much more than a similar Ranger but it had a ton more shit standard, got similar gas mileage, towed a ton more and generally had a lot better capability. Granted I bought mine before covid so the F150 XLT I got was like 2k more than a similarly specced Ranger but the F150 was just blatantly better for virtually the same price.

IMO the redpill is if you really need a truck that is somewhat smaller, or you'll never find yourself needing more towing than you originally planned for then a Ranger is for you but otherwise the F150 just isn't much more expensive and has way more overhead.
I found that the 2.3L ecobutt engine to lug a lot when paired to the 10 speed. This happens on the v6 ecoboost but it makes more torque so it doesn't feel like its lugging. It's really jarring because you'll gradually increase speed and the transmission will shift up and suddenly the truck will shudder like its going to stall. You gotta either use the stupid manual mode/sport mode or you gotta have a more lead foot in general.

>>26250698
I don't know when you bought, but when I was in the market for a truck last year there was no competition in price between the Ranger and F150, at least not if you wanted a 4x4 crew cab with any kind of decent options. There's an $8-10k difference between the two for similar features on paper and real life is more like $15k since dealers will actually sell you a Ranger for MSRP while F150s are flying out the door at $7,500-10k markup.
This isn't just me being a shitty car buyer or something either, I spent years in the auto industry and I'm still in the private industry FB groups, I've got friends/acquaintances from the corporate level down to dealers, etc., and the story is pretty damn consistent across the whole western US.

Also, I own a '20 Ranger and I haven't had the same lugging issues you describe. I get weird clunky shifts but it's usually when almost coasting at very low throttle or decelerating at low speeds. It just kicks down and goes when I put my foot into it, though the amount of go decreases with speed. (It kicks you in the ass if you floor it from less than 35 or so, but the power is just "decent" if you're trying to pass at 65+ or whatever.)

If you want to buy one just dont go with a JTS engine, they are horrible, shit power and shit reliability, especially the 3.2 V6 that has 20L/100km fuel consumption...

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248907
People in Europe just buy what they need to do their work, no more, no less. Minivans just work quite well, offering a lot of utility while keeping costs down (fuel consumption, buying price...) There's a lot of UTEs in my area tho, since it's related to agriculture (wine and sugar production), but why would an electrician working at the city get one? There's full size vans everywhere and pretty much every kind of work vehicle, even subcompact commercial cars like the Fiesta on picrel, but American trucks. Feeding a V8 in Europe would eat into the profits while offering barely any tangible work related benefit compared with what we are already using. For towing, semi-vans and semi-trucks of various sizes do that.

The most high performance oriented pickup model sold here is that Ford Ranger Raptor model which sits between the Maverick and the F150 with the 4cyl Mustang Ecoboost engine and Fox off-road suspension (Well, I haven't looked into the Gladiator or the G-Wagen pickup, maybe they have a competing model). Nobody buys them for work, just for fun. The average pickup here has a 120hp diesel engine, with the Hilux and the Mitsubishi L200 being the most popular.

>>26243737
>There’s no reason to get a minivan if you can get an SUV instead.
Not exactly. To match the utility case of a minivan, which is occupancy between 1-8 passengers and/or up to 140-150 cubic feet of cargo room, the SUV in question has to be a full-size, extended length SUV, otherwise the comparison isn't fair.

I'm going to use new cars so as not to complicate the data. The most common full-size, extended length SUV is a Chevrolet Suburban. It starts at $55,000. The most common minivan is a Toyota Sienna, which starts at $36,135. This is an immense price difference just in purchase costs, not to mention insurance, registration, and operations costs. The appropriately matched SUV simply costs more to own than a minivan.

Now, there are use cases where a minivan is the wrong tool for the job. This would be towing over 3.5k lbs and 4x4. In that case, a SUV makes sense.

This comparison also ignores that minivan buyers are extremely price conscious, and recommending too much car to them tends to make them very upset. They will notice every time they fill up the fuel tank. They will notice every oil change. They will notice tires, brakes, and all manner of other consumables, not to mention rego, insurance, repairs, etc. SUV buyers also tend to attach a particular status to the vehicle they drive and as a result are more willing to go high dollar for them, or modify/personalize them with high dollar items. As comedians have overplayed, minivan buyers don't quite give a shit, which is why they drive them. They just want the practicality.

The buyer for a minivan and a buyer for a comparable SUV are not the same people at all.

>>26246847
>Why does no one bring attention to the retarded regulations the nhtsa pushes out that leads to trucks getting this large?
The NHTSA wasn't the cause in particular. The testing encouraged automakers to make them "safer" which meant larger.

The large vehicle sizing primarily stems from how vehicles are regulated in the United States. The most commonly known one is CAFE, which no matter how it's regulated, encourages vehicles to be built larger to be graded more leniently. These days it's wheelbase x track width to fall under a particular vehicle class.

A lesser known one, and the one that REALLY encourages vehicles getting really fucking huge is 49 CFR § 523.5 (Title 49, Code of Federal Regulations, 523.5 - Non-Passenger Vehicles). It's very much possible to place vehicles in a non-passenger rating by utilizing 523.5 b.1.
>4-wheel drive
>greater than 6,000 GVWR
or 523.5 b.2
>approach angle of not less than 28°
>breakover angle of not less than 14°
>departure angle of not less than 20°
>running clearance of not less than 20 cm
>front and rear axle clearances of not less than 18 cm each

The most popular vehicles on sale utilize this to be "legally non-compliant", and this in particular is why aside from safety regs, vehicles are designed to be really large, and consumers are encouraged to purchase really large cars.

To give you an example, Toyota designs certain cars really weird because of this. Toyota enjoys receiving 98% of all CAFE credits (in no small part thanks to the Prius and tiny engined Corollas and Camries) and can end up designing cars like pic related to skirt regs in really weird ways. Technically the NX200t satisfies all the attack angles on paper.

12.6 is acceptable resting voltage. Noisy starters are (you hope) just an elderly starter motor. When you remove that inspect the flywheel/flex plate gear teeth with a bright light.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26242898
If this is a BMW or Audi or similar German car, the batteries have to be coded in. You can't just pull the old battery and put the new battery in.
Assuming you covered that already then:
Have you explored parasitic electricity loss?
Go to the auto parts store and have them test your battery. If the battery looks good then I would suspect something is drawing power while the car is off

>>26242939
I wonder if your transmission mount is going? Mounts for the engine and the transmission and the drivetrain in general are supposed to flex a little to help keep vibration out of the cockpit, but if they deteriorate or are old, they can flex too much and cause lag and wheel jump and all sorts of nonsense.

>>26243135

>>26243166
Springs don't wear out whether they're compressed or extended, they only wear out with use, so if your goal is to preserve the life of your shocks I would tie it down so that it's compressed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26245261
Could be a number of things but the most likley is that water (which is a byproduct from combustion) is precipitating in your cold exhaust pipe, and that when your exhaust heats up (as the engine does) it makes it out the end of the exhaust still in gaseous form. What you're seeing is condensation, not smoke. If it is smoke it could be your piston rings that seal better as your engine internals heat up, which causes your cold engine to consume a bit of oil.

>>26244291
There is a range of tires that will fit those wheel widths, you can look it up. Just be sure your tires fall within the recommended range, and then most importantly make sure that your overall diameter of your front and rear wheels are very close, like within .1".
So for example your 215 would probably be like a 45 aspect ratio and your 255s a 35 aspect ratio or something like that (I didn't look it up). Since that's the most important thing you may need to adjust your tire diameter as well as aspect ratios to find tires that have simillar OD front and back. If the OD is too far apart you can ruin the drivetrain if it's awd, and if it's not it could send your traction control and stability control into a panic.

>Can they fuck anything up
Unlikely. I probably wouldn't want to pressure wash the computer on an e-diff but most cars don't have that. You might also have vents on your differentials or transmission that could get water in there possibly. Overall unlikely to be an issue.
>What to grease?
I'm not sure if they mean chassis lube points or like corrosion resistance application but I assume the former. Some cars require regular greasing of things like the ball joints, steering rack and other moving parts and other cars are sealed for life and don't need chassis greasing. Usually it's work vehicles like heavy duty trucks that have grease points. Check you owners manual or Google it for your car.

Alright /o/, I'm on the verge of madness. I have a 1989 Buick Skyhawk with the good old 122 4. And something is fucky with its cooling system. After it's warmed up, if I'm sitting at idle for a bit (like at a red light) then start to go, I hear bubbles in the coolant (as they pass through the heater core). When I get home and let it cool down, sure enough, some coolant is gone.

The heater core isn't leaking. The radiator hoses aren't leaking. The heater core hoses aren't leaking. The radiator isn't leaking. The radiator cap isn't leaking. The water pump isn't leaking. The transmission cooler ports aren't leaking. Hot coolant is flowing out through the overflow tube (confirmed by feel and thermal camera). There's no coolant in the oil. There's no oil in the coolant. I got my own gas detector in the coolant thingy and it shows nothing. I've replaced the water pump. I've replaced the head gasket (so also new intake manifold gasket & EGR manifold gasket). I've replaced the whole god damned head (amazingly, you can still buy heads for this engine). I've tried two different radiator caps. The radiator itself is not original, it's an all-aluminum piece.

What the fuck. I'm now suspecting, in order:
1. Cracked EGR manifold (would suck because these are only found in junkyards now)
2. Cracked intake (wet intake, also EGR gas flows through the intake)
3. Cracked block

How can I diagnose this? Is there any clear tubing that I can get to try and see if bubbles are coming from somewhere, something that can withstand the heat and pressure?

folks, I didn't want to create a thread for this question, so here it is :

- I have an audi with the 3.2 vr6
Took it to the mechanic for an oil change. He put some 5w30 synthetic oil in it. everything was fine, and it didnt bother me much as I knew no better (no change in noise, behavior or anything). One day, while I was driving it hard (that was 5000 kilometres after the oil change), I got a message on the dash saying " oil pressure low, turn off engine". I turned off the engine immediately. I noticed the oil temperature was 120 degrees celcius (248 fahrenheit). I let it cool down for 30 minutes, and drove it back home slowly. the oil temperature remained normal for the whole drive home (between 90 and 100 degrees celcius). Ever since that day, I have clocked in an additional 3000 kilometres with it, but never pushed the engine hard, and the temperature of the oil has remained normal. I am taking it to the garage tomorrow, and changing to 5w40 synthetic (which appears to be the recommended viscosity).
My question is: Is my engine fucked ? It drives normal, does not consume much oil at all, the dipstick is almost at the exact same level as the day when I changed it, and I never have to top it up. Anyone got any experience with that kind of things ? Thank you for reading my blog!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248477
We'll start with the most serious issue: The cracked block.
If it was cracked externally, you'd doubtless have found the leak by now.
If it was cracked internally, you definitely notice symptoms such as fluid contamination. Given you state that's not happening, nor is it building too much pressure, then I'm optimistic you can rule out the block/head/head gasket.

Likewise, if the EGR manifold/cooler assembly has started leaking, you'll be able to tell as exhaust gases would be present to some degree in the coolant, darkening it. If not darkening it, then a sniffer test would detect the presence of coolant. They're a simple kit to buy and use.

Failing that, we're left with the wet intake manifold as the most likely cause of the three you've listed.
Testing it (and the EGR manifold, if it comes to it) is easy - if a little awkward.
Basically block one pipe, and find some way to fit a tyre valve to the other. Inflate to 20 psi, use water/suds to make sure your pipe block/valve arent leaking and observe any pressure drop. Over, say, half an hour. A leaking component will have lost it's pressure.

Or you can remove the components completely, then submerge them like a tyre tube and look for bubbles.

Also, take out your spark plugs. If it's the EGR or the intake, then ALL the plugs should have signs of burning coolant.
If only one or two plugs have it, then it's an engine issue.
The coolant-fouled plug is on the right

>>26240792

The L15B has poor engine oiling, tiny crankshaft with poor rod to stroke ratios which prevent the engine from wanting to rev. The rods are weak and bend or shatter above 250whp. They also have tiny rod bolts which are smaller than an average 10mm oil pan nut. This causes the bolts to fail under stress lunching the engine. The head bolts are undersized which cause head gasket problems. Everything about the engine is designed to be as cheap as possible and to save money on gas, not make power. The only people who defend them do it because they own a car with one in it.

posts.name: Sage
posts.com:
>>26242193
They won't be making that much power for very long. Theres a video on YouTube that shows some differences between L15 parts and other honda engines like K20,D16 etc. The l15 crankshaft is about 2/3rds the size of a d16 crankshaft and has tiny balancers and small journals. The rods are much smaller than a k20 and the rod bolts are 3 sizes smaller. The oil galley grooves on the block mains are small and on the center main all oil pressure comes from a single pinhole. No crank girdle to be found. The oil pump gears apparently shatter with increased power or can score and lose oil pressure. The torque to yield head bolts are of a lower quality metal then the K series ones.

This isn't a case of "new engine bad", the l15b is a cost cutting economy engine Honda threw in its Civic SI to save costs and there aren't alot of safety margins built into it once you exceed stock output.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I lost my dad to cancer in September of 2020 and lost my mom to the same in october of 2020. I doubt your parent's will pass within weeks like mine did, but I believe that my point is still salient. You probably do not want to be around day in and day out at the end. I moved out at 18, grad school at 22, bought a house, got married, had a daughter etc etc... typical american dream shit. When my mom and dad got really sick I ended up spending an enormous amount of time at their house because the writing was on the wall and I wanted to get in as much time as I could. As noble as that sounds, the experience was truly scarring. My dad had brain cancer my mom bone cancer (stemming from breast cancer or so the doctors believed) , and seeing a once proud man that cold shrug off a broken bone not be able to feed himself and watching my loving, caring mom lash out at me in ways that would never have happened in the past because she was panicked abut dying has fucked me up for the rest of my life. Luckily, I'm 38 and as I said, have my own family that I can focus on. I probably wouldn't even change anything if given the opportunity, and if this weren't an anonymous board, I'd probably not even bring it up, but from someone that's lived it...you're going to want some space when that happens.

>>26240106
I'm 32 and still live at home. My situation was similar to >>26240199, I lived in an apartment by myself paying well over $1k each month with barely any furnishings making $32k a year, driving a 2009 Scion xD with 140k miles on it that I paid $4k for, asshole neighbors that bitched every time I'd play my guitar above a single decibel yet have their hood parties outside constantly, street parking, no room to study so I went to the library constantly which meant driving a car I hated and fitting travel time into my tight schedule. I was only happy when I was hiking and since I live in PA that's only viable 3 months out of the year.
Moved back in with my parents and pay them for utilities each month. My folks didn't want me to pay anything but I demanded they take at least something and we settled on $200 a month. I have a much better car that I actually enjoy driving, I can play guitar in peace, I can study in peace (currently going for my MBA), and I can sleep in peace. I'm still young, my dad was selling lawnmowers at Sears when he was my age and now he's a federal employee making six figures. My plan is to get the material shit out of the way first (sports car, guitar, amp, fancy computer, etc.) and get the house last when the prices aren't retarded. I don't plan on having kids anyway, I have five younger siblings that I had to help raise, I got that shit out of my system early.

>>26240120
As unpopular as it sounds, this is the move unless you are extremely happy living at home. If all you want to do is spend money on cars and save for a home, then more power to you, I've been doing it for the last 8 years of my life. Bailed myself out of an absurd amount of debt, am max funding my 401k and saving 3-4k a month for a house.

That said, I'm here at 28 letting everyone younger know, there are benefits to having that freedom that I see in many of my friends. Although I clearly have much more material wealth and security than they do, they are generally happier people. There's a certain amount of socialization and development that they have went through that being at home just doesn't allow for unless your parents are extremely liberal (sex, drugs, parties etc.). Weigh the pros and cons wisely, if I could go back and do it all over I definitely wouldn't but I'm also an incel that would rather detail my car for 2 hours instead of go to bars and talk with people.

>>26247482
Unironically, you're in a cool position because you have nothing to loose. Traditional expectations and general norms don't apply to you anymore. If you stick to your little bubble and waste away alone until your end, you'll live a miserable last few years of your life.
If I were you with no responsibilities and no ties, I'd sell all my shit to put some cash in my pocket, and just start driving. Stop in home-town bars, bullshit with people, see the wonders of your country (wherever that may be), since nearly everywhere has something cool to see. Create as many experiences as you can, since you're no longer obligated to give a fuck about anything.
By the end, you're either going to decide that life is worth living after meeting some people and building your world view, or you're going to run out of cash and off yourself anyways, but at least you did some cool shit before the end.
You can't change shit that already happened to you, but you can change the way shit will go. Godspeed, anon.

>>26241445
Yes. There was a short period of time in the late 80s and early 90s where it was approaching mainstream popularity, but it died pretty quickly because the championship started to be dominated by foreign drivers and they started moving away from the Oval roots. IRL broke away to try and avoid the problems CART had, but the competing championships ended up dividing viewership more (with the people who wanted ovals and American drivers all jumping ship to NASCAR which was at its peak of popularity then, and the people who didn’t mind the internationalism just went to F1). Nowadays the only people who care about Indy are midwesterners, and even then it’s really only the Indy 500.

>>26242427
I think I get why the games seem to fall apart, the hierarchal structure of frostbite makes changing one thing very complicated if it's not like a single float value or something. There's no real way to just turn UI elements off and on, everything you want needs to be written down all the way up the ladder.
For example the way the controls work is strange: the game identifies and has separate mappings for different types of controllers but instead of just saying internally "ok button 1 for controller 1 is gas, button 2 is brake, controller 1 is not an Xbox pad so I will use the steering wheel handling rules" they let the game engine figure out specifically what kind of controller you're using and map "concepts" to "actions" then to a generic layout that is pre-set with all the buttons and axes the game should expect to see for each supported controller, It seemingly has no idea what the actual controller axes and buttons are, probably why heat needed g-hub for any wheels to work.

shit is stupid and is a good example of why big game companies and monolithic multipurpose engines were a mistake
all the dumb fucks that could have put a button rebinding menu in NFS are busy rescuing Battlefield

Announcing /ovg/ Sunday Cup - an upcoming (no firm date yet but expect February) series in Assetto Corsa where you pick and choose your own car.

Rules are a little bit complicated for this one so read the wiki: http://wiki.get-good.net/index.php?title=/ovg/_Sunday_Cup but the tl;dr for you is this: Find a car listing in the permitted countries with a car worth at most 2000 euros, and a maximum of 200 bhp. You may ONLY choose a car noone else has chosen the same body style of, ie. you can have a BMW E92 and a BMW E30 in the series, but no two BMW E92s regardless of type. posts.name: Anonymous

>>26247963
>>26247992
TRD was originally their racing development crew based out of Japan. They developed things like the Group C sports cars and the various Group A homologation specials of the 80s.
GR is short for Gazoo Racing, Gazoo being what they renamed Toyota Team Europe about 15 years ago. TTE, as the name implies, is based out of Germany and originally wasn’t even an official factory outfit for Toyota. TRD and GR developed independently of each other on separate continents, but as the Japanese racing team withered away the European one flourished. So Toyota decided to drop the TRD name and move to GR. The only exception being in the US because the TRD name is strongly associated with the Tacoma and Tundra.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
First prerequisite is you must be able to wrench yourself at least the basic stuff. More as you get further into the mods. Why? Most shops won't touch heavily modded cars because they don't know what they're getting into, you'll have to go to tuning shops even for maintenance work.
Secondly I'd upgrade first the air intake, cooling system, piping, exhaust headers, intake manifold and exhaust system before putting too much power into the engine.
After that, you can add real power to it. If you don't have a turbo, get a turbo kit. If you do have a turbo, either get a bigger one or have yours rebuilt. Complete that with bigger injectors and better fuel pump.
Then late stage you can upgrade the pistons, get race cams, race clutch and lighter flywheel, maybe even the whole transmission if you want faster gear ratios for example.
Brakes are also important but no need for meme Brembos. I got SUV calipers and discs on my light coupe because it's from the same brand and year as that SUV. So they're cheap brakes that are made to stop a car that's more than double the weight of mine. So just look into bigger discs and calipers instead of same size Brembos

Maybe this will explain it to you, I'm coming from a place of wisdom on the subject, not fear or ignorance:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KxuYCwtWjes

It's also ignorant as shit to think all cars are made to "bean counter specs", they're made to specs that passed insanely rigorous testing in all sorts of extreme environments (hot, cold, wet, rocky roads, etc). Modern cars have an insanely good balance of ride quality to handling that is usually already optimal for real world road driving. Putting rock hard lowering springs on a car primarily driven on the road is actually going to make it slower as tires bound over bumps and lose contact with the road. We already know what a nightmare grenade modern engines are with any serious power mods compared to some understressed 70's car that can happily have bolt ons, a cam, and a carb tune and make that power all day long because it doesn't have to meet smog anymore. None of my cars are completely stock, there's always here and there small things I've done to them, but I don't turn them into tuner grenades that ride like a rock with wheels bolted to it and require an old priest and a young priest to diagnose it when something goes wrong. There are road cars and there are race cars, I own road cars and I rent race cars because ownership of race cars is a terrible proposition, simple as.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249844
You're only now specifying your distain towards modifying "modern" cars and building excessively over-the-top big horsepower builds for the street, which in that case, I more or less agree with you. Your previous posts sound like you're shitting on any sort of wrenching/improvement/tinkering with your car, regardless of age, model, needs, or wants, which is a retarded take.
>It's also ignorant as shit to think all cars are made to "bean counter specs"
Except they are? Factory vehicles are designed to suit the needs of as many people as possible, so the performance figures are engineered to be smack in the middle of the target demographic's assumed wants. The aftermarket will nearly always produce a better quality product than OEM because their R+D cost allowances for the given part are higher. I never claimed you have to put your car on rock hard lowering springs on your car, but you can bet that an expensive aftermarket suspension system is going to have higher quality materials and better adjustability so you can dial it in how you want if you just so happen to fall outside of those assumed demographic needs. Is it a requirement for all cars? Certainly not. Are there some cars that could use some help from the factory? Absolutely.
>ownership of race cars is a terrible proposition
Monetarily? Definitely. For consistency and racing at an amateur level, I disagree. There's something to be said for putting the same car that you own around different tracks and personally dialing it in. However, it only makes sense if you frequent the track enough to get enough use out of it that it's worth the headache.
I've had a few spec cars in my time, and I spent a year as a mechanic for a track rental experience company where I often drove our rentals near the limit. The seat time in a rental is always enjoyable, but I personally find seat time in my own track shitbox more satisfying. Also, dial back on sucking your own dick, christ man.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249981
>Are there some cars that could use some help from the factory? Absolutely.

I already covered that. It's one thing to fix a known reliability or usability issue, it's another to turn your engine into a grenade with an aftermarket turbo kit. Even the highest grade turbo kits will never get as good or reliable as OEM.

>For consistency and racing at an amateur level, I disagree

If you seriously want to race a season you kind of have no choice, but the expense of doing so is so high that IMO the value proposition is with renting, even though it's annoying to have to adjust to a different car each time. We all know racing is expensive as shit and very few have the money to truly just say "fuck it" and spend whatever they want to do it whatever way they want. Even people that are rich by everyman standards still find themselves stifled when it comes to affording racing. Big difference between paying for a single track day during the 3-4 months a year the weather is nice vs. owning a race car, tow vehicle/trailer, workspace, lift, tools, spares, hiring a few guys to come to the track to fix it if something breaks since 1 person will not get it fixed in time, etc. You'll find many people that own their own race car that aren't balls to the wall rich are also mechanics or something very similar as their day job as it's the only way they can afford access to all of the shit you need to keep a race car running competitively.

posts.com: the stock speaker on the drivers side of my 6th gen celica is starting to distort at medium volume, thinking of replacing it with an aftermarket. Found a good adapter already, but not sure what speaker brand I should put in? needs to be 6.5 inch 400 watt. I don't plan on adding an amp/sub addon, car is too rattly for it to have any serious sound system mods.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248038
check the oem speaker impedance, iirc nips all use 4 ohm impedance speakers. should be on the back of the speaker itself, where the magnet is. if you install a different impedance speaker it'll be distorted.
If using with factory head unit, look for speakers with a high sensitivity. around 89 db is fine, but higher is always better. watts rms doesn't need to be too high with stock head units too.
I think toyota generally uses 5.25 inch speakers in the door, but take it out and confirm. And also confirm if it's a component or coax speaker, then pick from there.
Alternatively crutchfield has a speaker selector where you can pick what car you have and it'll give you options that fit

posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249547
>Self service or pressure washer at home
>Spray until dirt is gone then use squeegee and shammy leather for the rest
Since I own an offroad-ish truck I don't really care much about dirt on the outside. As long as my headlights work and I can take a look out of the windows I'm fine.
I spend more time cleaning the interior
>Thick rubber mats on the floor
>Start by removing all the shit in the glove box and other compartments.
>vacuum clean the entire interior, combined with a soft brush for those hard-to-reach spots like rotary switches (pro-tip: Shaving cream brushes)
>Damp cloth to wipe over all surfaces to remove residual dust and other shit
>Use windex to clean glass and mirrors real good. I'm really anal about that.
>Put some light grease on the seat rails (sometimes)
>Use a piece of cloth with a light(!!!!!!!!) coat of Ballistol on all the plastic and rubber parts. After that it's necessary to let the truck air out for an hour to remove the Ballistol stench. But I found out it's a real good protection for plastics and rubber and also gives them a nice shine. Since I don't really soak the cloth they also don't get slippery/oily at all.
>Put all the stuff back into the glove box and other compartments.
>Top off windshield washing fluid if necessary
>Take a seat, put on the radio and drink a beer while enjoying the clean truck for a few moments.
That's my usual regimen. No fixed dates, more like "every other month or so if I think it's necessary"

posts.sub: You are robbing a major bank. What vehicles are you choosing?
posts.com:
In this scenario you will be robbing a major bank in Manhatten, NYC.This will be divided into stages.

1. Initial robbery: a discreet vehicle to carry a 3 man crew including yourself.

2. First escape vehicle: a vehicle parked across the street from the bank thats fast enough to escape police vehicles but nimble enough to make it through NYC traffic. (you can have multiple if theyre 2 seaters.

3. Vehicle swap for a highway chase: you make it to a major interstate and swap into a more fitting vehicle. which option will you choose? pure speed? a vehicle good for ramming for the inevitable police blockades ahead you will face?

4. your lay low vehicle. a vehicle that goes unnoticed while you escape the country or make it to a small town. are you going full npc with a nissan rogue, or do you want a sleeper in case a rogue hero cop spots you and you need to make another getaway?

5. your celebration vehicle. you did it. you successfully pulled off a heist. what new car are you treating yourself with?

>Manhattan, NYC
>Initial robbery:
Dirt cheap, high mileage black Town Car
>First escape vehicle:
White Ford Transit Ecoboost/Chevrolet Express V8/duramax done up to look like a full on tradie van (with at least two or three sets of removable magnet company logos on hand), but with a decent quality low profile push bar since you're not getting through heavy traffic without moving people out of the way
>Vehicle swap for a highway chase:
Debadged W220 S55 AMG, an N54 powered BMW E60/F10 5 series or E70 X5, or an Ecoboost late model AWD Explorer. All are easily tunable for more power and cheap to pick up. Sedans would be more stable at high speeds, but the SUVs would have the advantage of ground clearance if you need to go off the side of the road for any reason.
>Your lay low vehicle
A ~10 year old Grand Cherokee with a supercharged hemi or full-on Hellcat swap. You could exchange this for any of the 'highway chase' options too.
>Your celebration vehicle
If I ever learned anything from watching movies such as Goodfellas, you never go out and blow cash after a heist especially on a new car. I think paying cash on old shitboxes for less than $20k might not pick up much heat, I'd either go scoop up an '80s Regal T-Type or a '70s-'80s 2-door Cadillac of some sort until the heat dies down so I can buy the expensive stuff.

ahh the 3vz-e, the black sheep of the vz engine family. trd built a 400 hp one for baja or dakar or something. last time i saw it was on ebay, dunno who has it now.
iirc the ball joint thing was a design flaw on all early tacos and 96-04 4runners where the ball joint was constantly trying to get pulled out of its socket, causing earlier and more catastrophic failure compared to the revised design after this period where the ball joint is instead compressed into its socket. aftermarket parts would fail much earlier than the oem parts simply because the oem ones were just so much beefier so they gave more warning time before failing completely. The ball joints would also fail if the securing nut wasn't torqued to spec and in some cases people didn't use the cotter pin. The bolts also weren't reusable; who knows how many DIYers didn't know about this either.

I dont know about trucks. But I know cars for most of gasoline engines its good to check engine oil level from cold engine before running the engine, easiest to top up the oil level to correct level without any risk of burning a hand. If I check oil level in less than 10-15minutes after drive its easy to accidentallly add too much oil because there's lots of oil at upper parts of engine. lets not forget that most of engine oil returns into oil pan when engine is not running, some engines even drain the oil from oil filter into oil pan. Most of dipsticks measure oil level directly from oil pan, not from other parts of the engine.

In Europe, it was decided that the King would be replaced by parliament, with the constitution subservient to it.

The UK and Ireland have essentially abolished common law, and adopted continental civil law in all but name. The groundwork for this was laid when they established the concept of parliamentary supremacy during the Cromwellian era, and is in fact what led to the american revolution in the first place (Westminster, following parliamentary supremacy, decided to overrule constitutional principle in the colonies).

Thanks for posting the video, I`ve never watched and I`ll make some considerations about it, but beforehand let me tell that I`ve worked for Deere dealerships around the globe and currently work for Deere itself so my views are from the perspective of a company worker.

What the farmer it's complaining its about the dtac info that could have saved him thousands of dollars. I get his frustration, but in my point of view (as a Deere technician) its the knowledge contained in the dtac its intelectual proprietary of the brand.

Could it be released for free to the clients? Yes, but the people pulling the strings have decided that it would hurt our margins and do not share the info.

Ive had a lot of arguments past year in the country that I`m currently located because some DTAC shared info with 3rd party technicians, that in my point of view was better share the info and get the machine running then let a green equipment stopped during the planting season. Did I`ve hurt the profits of the dealer? Yes. Did I made the client happy and a green machine running. Yes, which is on the long term, a better deal with the brand.

I`m not saying that Deere its always right, but we have to catch a common ground with the clients and the company.

We have mouths to feed and we have to make money, so does the farmer. I don't believe that we should share everything because a lot of those DTACs had a lot of investment in technicians, parts, research to reach a solution, so we have to be rewarded by this effort.

tl, dr Deere is a cashgrab whore and the farmers always want everything for free.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26248083
Blutooth dongle.

It’s kind of annoying because you’re going to have to pay for licenses and download different apps for certain cars, but for a $20 bluetooth module and ~$20 per car license purchases, you can get the functionality of like a $500+ scan tool.

This is from somebody who owns 2 standalone scan tools and recently got one of those Veepeak modules. The $25 Veepeak can send commands to change the damn radio station and my $150 Autel can’t do anything close to that.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26248083
>>26248091
But also the $20 bluetooth module with a free app will give you the function of a ~$50 standalone scan tool. You can still read typical codes and erase stuff. The $15-$25 license for each car (depending on the app, like there’s some good all around apps and some brand specific apps) will get you deep into the car’s computer. Before I bought that Veepeak, I was reading a lot of reviews and those are popular with BMW goys because they can reprogram shit with some Bimmer app and their smartphone.

So can’t really lose. It’s free to check basic codes on a friend’s car, and not that expensive if you have some retarded project where you need to go deep with diagnostics.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249436
Also, that sounds horrifically slow. You must not know how flat rate pay works. I get paid one hour to diagnose a car regardless of how long it actually takes. The snap on software isn't just for CAN access, it's also the "intelligent diagnostics" that give you immediate access to test procedures, connector pinouts, system function descriptions, real fixes, smart data (watches relevant PIDs and dings when something irregular shows up), etc. That way I generally don't have to dick around on Mitchell/AllData/Identifix etc trying to find what I need, it's all right there while I'm standing next to the car. Also, it sounds like you don't have bidirectional functionality (basically the scan tool can force the car to do certain functions when I want, like commanding the fuel pump relay on or something). A lot of OEM diagnostic trees require this functionality. It's also a lab scope/multimeter, if you didn't catch that.

>>26247431
3D printed parts aren't really great for long term use. The UV exposure and heat will weaken and deform the plastic. The layer lines are very weak and will likely break after long term exposure to vibrations and flexing back and forth from wind and acceleration. Also the brake fluid itself would likely destroy the plastic if it ever dripped onto it. Parts with a high aspect ratio like a mount for the brake fluid reservoir would be particularly susceptible to breaking.

3D printers are great and I use mine for a lot of things, but I wouldn't use it for this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26247520
The GS500 is objectively the best beginner bike.
> mileage
It's a mid-sized 4stroke twin cylinder bike, so it drinks less than 6 liters per 100 km.
> handling
It handles nothing like a supersport, spoiling you for when you get something else. But it can also corner much better than something like a cruiser, and actually uses its entire rear tire unlike a Ninja 250.
> brakes
They are complete shit and their only redeeming feature is that they're disc brakes. This is good because the longer braking distance forces new riders to plan ahead and start braking early. No ABS means they learn to brake properly I'd they don't want to get shrekt.
> power
It sits right at the power limit for A2 bikes which is great for euros. It's torquey enough to be faster off the line than most cars you'll encounter in the city. But it also feels relatively gutless so a) it's forgiving of mistakes and b) you can ride it at the limit without putting yourself into too much danger. It reaches up to 180 km/h which is fast enough for highway riding.
> carbs
It being carbed means that if you run into problems, you can learn to fix them yourself instead of heading to the mechanic every time.
> seating position
Upright, slightly forward means it's a neutral riding position so you can figure out what you want afterwards. The seat is relatively uncomfortable making literally every other bike after it will feel like heaven on your ass.
> price and availability
Parts and the bikes themselves are cheap and plentiful. If you crash and fuck up one of your fairings it's 40 euros to replace it with original parts. Engine needs little maintenance. Beginner riders are typically not financially independent, so this is a big plus for them.
> suspension
It's a budget suspension factoring into the overall low cost of getting a GS 500. If you want better suspension it's easy to swap. Therefore it gives beginners an opportunity to learn working on suspension while keeping the cost manageable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26247564
PETG will hold up better than PLA to the heat and sun, but is prone to fracture very easily in sudden impacts. ABS has better mechanical properties than PETG with similar heat resistance, but the shrinkage problem makes it want to split at the layers when you do a wide part, which could force you to print it tall instead which makes the layer line problem worse.
Depending on the application and how you design it, you could have forces in all direction so there's no avoiding the layer line problem. You can probably do OK for the reservoir mount though.
>never keep a bike more than a couple years
Yeah you could probably make it work long enough to make it the next guy's problem. Repeatedly replacing parts on a vehicle would be annoying though.

>>26247564
>I would count on brake fluid ruining almost anything

Yep. The plastic markings on brake fluid jugs indicate type of plastic. You could use them to find if that plastic is available as a filament. If ya find one that works pls post.

Racers and wannabes often toss damaged reservoirs and use clear Tygon tubing filled with an irrigation syringe (cheap, handy at any drug store). The syringe is used to pressure bleed the systems without needing a modded reservoir cap since no reservoir. It works passably.

Fancy delete kit example. Non-remote masters are sometimes tapped for a hose barb but the body casting's too thin for me to be that brave risking the bore. This one has a pneumatic check valve to mimic stock caps so atmospheric pressure properly forces fluid into the bore.

https://spearsenterprises.com/product/rear-brake-fluid-reservoir-delete-kit/

>>26248237
For 20 brazilian shitcoins, you can get 250ml of industrial degreaser, and for another 10, a set of small wire brushes. And also buy the cheapest wide paint brush you can get. The harder the fur, the better.
Mix a small amount of industrial degreaser with water (1 part of degreaser to 10 parts of water, do not try to saturate the solution, as it will not work as intended) and using a brush apply it over your COLD engine. When you finish it, wash it with a hose and do it again, but this time, use the wire brush to clean it.
I swear it will look 500 times better.

I advise you to wear gloves as the industrial degreaser is strong and will eat your skin, but nothing that bad. Just don't get it on your eyes...

>>26249959
Surprised you don't have a durometer tester.
Anyways sport bike tires are generally still pretty grippy as they get older. Especially if left in a cool garage, or garage in general. Sun+heat ages tires fast.
If they grip well for you then use them. I had a pair of 13yr old bridgetsone battlax sport tires that gripped well, but those were stored in a cool garaged place(I presume). If they have bad cracking or seem really hard on the finger nail test only use them on dry warm days, or ditch them.

Cruiser tires that start hard get really sketch as they age. Go from low grip to no grip in the rain.

>>26248464
>once the demand rises
This gets overplayed. Every gallon of gas burned to drive 25 miles in the average ICE vehicle today took about 6kWh of electricity to get into the fuel tank for that to happen.
6kWh put into a typical 4 mile a kWh BEV today will go 24 miles on that same 6kWh. So if every vehicle on the road was magically a BEV tomorrow, demand would only increase marginally.

With 5 and 6 mile a kWh BEVs coming to market, demand may actually decrease slightly. A 6 mile a kWh BEV would drive 36 miles on the same 6kWh. More efficient BEVs are also more practical for owners to run on their own solar generation with some designs where the solar panels are integrated into the vehicle able to add about their needed daily use when parked out in the sun.

>It is highly unlikely that charging once a week will be enough, especially as the cars gets older.
Even a 70% degraded long range car at the end of its life will still have more range than a short range car. Charging once a week overnight, or a couple of times a week for 1 hour in the middle of the night really just comes down to personal preference and the cost of electricity. Its probably cheaper to charge a couple of times a week for 1 hour, than for a few hours less frequently.

>while charging it overnight is a sound strategy, can you guarantee that that will be enough?
For the vast majority of daily use and weekend trips? Yes. Keep in mind that 250 mile range is pretty typical for affordable BEVs today, and the whole reason gas cars have 300 miles of range is so they can go about 2 weeks in normal use without refueling.
One night a week, or one hour periodically can easily cover daily use, and when you make a longer drive? Its just an overnight charge to be back up to full.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26248544
>How do you figure?
Refineries have electrical use measured in terrawatt hours, more than some whole cities. The pumps that extract oil from the ground, and move it in pipelines also use significant amounts of electricity. Then of course gas stations have to keep their lights on, and they also use electric pumps to move the fuel up into your gas tank.
6kWh is actually the low end of estimates. At the high end BEVs already use less electricity than even really exceptional internal combustion vehicles.

The TLDR is that the switch over to BEVs is probably only going to be a small part of the necessary grid upgrades that will be done over the next 30+ years as old dirty coal is phased out in favor of modern safe and clean Nuclear power.

posts.com:
I've been looking at part numbers, spec sheets and compatibility charts again.
Turns out the brake setup on the Espace 1/2 is very similar to the Clio Williams, which is identical to the one found on late 16V Twingos (same caliper mounting hole spacing, same brake disc diameter, they even take the same brake pads), but with one crucial difference: the Espace calipers get much bigger pistons (54mm vs 48mm).
They also cost less than 50 eurobucks a pop brand new. Might need a new master cylinder to compensate for the increased pedal travel but this is all very promising, it's not quite a big brake kit but it should all still just barely fit under 14" wheels and get you some extra stopping power.

Also if you upgrade to 15x6-7" wheels you can run Goodyear Eagle F1s in 195/45R15, which sounds hilarious for trackday sessions.

>>26250652
The problem with synthetic gasoline is that to make 33.7 kWh of fuel, you need about 62kWh of electricity. At current rates best case scenario that's about $8 a gallon, $.32 a mile. Of course it requires additional resources and the process isn't scaled up to be that efficient yet which is why right now its about $25 a gallon / $1 a mile.
That's never going to fly until they get to volume production, and its unlikely that spinning up volume production will happen until subsidies for fossil fuels have a sunset date.

Put that same 62kWh into an electric car and that same $8 of electricity will drive 248 miles, $.03 a mile.

Yes building out clean abundant nuclear power makes synthetic fuels potentially much more affordable, but anything that lowers the cost of electricity makes BEVs that much cheaper to drive.

In a "bold" attempt at shitbox dress shoe design, the 1947 Davis Divan was an attempt at the three-wheeled car that ultimately ended in a similar vein as the Reliant Robin did in the UK, just a good thirty years prior to what is called the "Fiberglass Pig."

Its main selling point was its extremely good fuel economy for the day due to it being lightweight, and its ability to do tight donuts at a circumference of around 17 ft thanks to its single front wheel design. Its flaws, should be obvious even if they're to be considered "design choices."

Around fifty remain from the original production line as of today. >>26239093
yeah i never changed mine because it got 26mpg highway with the 6, everyone was telling me i wouldn't be happy without 3.08's or 3.27's

if you have an egr there's a specific way to set it up, otherwise it will bog straight off idle, most people delete it and since you have a 351 it might not even be much benefit

i was happy *enough* after i swapped to a clutch fan, de-catted, and recurved my distributor, but i ended up never upgrading my carb because the goofy intake on my car

ford heads are typically restricted on the exhaust port if you were willing to do a little more work, but intake, exhaust, and the other little things should give you a nice boost

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
VAN TREASURE HUNT UPDATE:
This sort of applies as a classic, even though this thing was manufactured in 1992 Brazil. It's a VW Kombi camper van, manufactured exactly as it had been for over 30 years at that point, except with a modern engine for its day. No EFI, straight carburation. If it doesn't apply here, then I'll shut up about it here and not speak on it again. But I think most of us understand that Central and South American car culture persisted in continuing manufacturing aftermarket designs long after the original production run.

Over in Houston, GF and I came across a remarkable deal and made friends of the sellers, as they were prioritizing their home repairs over the dream car. Runs and drives, and because they liked us, are giving us an incredible discount (From 7k -> 6k without even attempting to haggle). The only major rust spots are in the front captain seats - everything else is remarkably good shape. They were inviting us out to dinner as we were getting ready to leave, so absolutely made a great impression. Incredible energy and vibes coming from the young couple, so I made a DIY friend in the process. Absolutely stellar. I told them we'd have to think about the purchase itself; but when my woman sat in the driver's seat, she immediately felt completely at home. So now more than ever, she's ready to commit to this hobby even if we hadn't handed over a check yet.

pre smog cams are pretty decent

there's not much to gain unless you increase the powerband or narrow your LSA

to narrow your LSA and make decent gains you would need some substantual exhaust work ie longtubes & port match

if you do a cam take note that a lot of replacement cam gears are inherently 4 degrees retarded as this is what ford did after 1972

>>26239690
I said avoid edelbrock.
They're garbage.
>To adjust float level on an Edelbrock, turn the top upside down and measure the distance from the tip of the float to the air horn gasket; it should be 7/16-inch. If adjustments are necessary, carefully bend the arm on the float with needle nose pliers.
That way is shit and never guarantees the fuel level is correct, which affects fuel delivery through the carb.
Whereas on a holley the needle and seat are screw-in and there's a weep hole on the side of the float bowl.
Remove weep hole plug and screw the need and seat up or down until fuel level is at the weep hole.

>>26243733
That depends entirely on where you're located and what body style you like.
I chose a Ford Pinto because it's hilarious. That, and, it's an excellent entry level vehicle made simple in automotive respects, ease of customizing in mind. That, and I really enjoy the scavenger hunt for parts in scrapyards.

What's your fancy? Pre-war? Midcentury? Malaise muscle?
You have to pick what you like, and then run with it and run hard. What tools do you have at your disposal, and how much work do you plan on doing? Pick an interesting and underutilized vehicle if you want to buy really low, but expect the search to be hard. If you want something easier to find parts for, go for something more well known.

Remember, you will get what you pay for in your initial buy-in, unless you're lucky. If you buy extra low, expect extra low grade stuff.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26237901
+1 on Everstarts.

There’s only a couple OEMs that make all of those batteries for the parts stores and big box retailers. I have used them all in the fleet of cars I’m always taking care of. They all last like +/-3mos of the warranty period, could be a Duralast Gold or DieHard or Everstart.

Everstarts at Walmart are always like 30% cheaper than the auto parts stores. Like the Gold (4yrs?) at Walmart is the same price as the standard (3yr) at the auto parts stores. Plus the Everstart 3 year warranty is a real 3 year warranty. Some of the parts stores like AutoZone prorate the last year, so Duralast 3 year warranty batteries are really only 2 year free replacement. If a $160 Duralast 3yr dies at 2 years 9 months, they will give you $40 towards the new battery. It pissed me off so much the one time I called to see if a dead battery was still under warranty, guy on the phone told me it was, but it was only like 2 months left and I got $25 towards the new one, it would’ve been cheaper to go to Walmart where the battery was like $40 cheaper.

Also Walmart has easy returns. They will go by the sticker on the battery if you don’t have a receipt, and most of the time they don’t even test it. I’ve heard lots of stories of AutoZone dudes wanting to put it on a charger overnight and dragging ass to replace batteries under warranty.

And if you get shit from one Walmart manager, just go back when their shift ends.

I really hate supporting Walmart, but you can get an Everstart Gold with a real 4 year warranty in most sizes that costs about the same as a Duralast standard with a 2 year replacement + 1 year prorated. Since I’m in Florida with the heat and AC blasting and lots of short commutes, that full warranty helps because literally the past 10 batteries I have replaced are all within a couple months of the warranty date. So buying them from Walmart, the ones that die at 34-35 months get replaced for free which saves me $$$.

Autozone is also a shit show, sometimes you have a battery that’s losing power slowly and if you load test a big 900CCA truck battery with a basic tester, it might not drop much with a 100A load but struggles to start the vehicle. And dumb Autozone kids might hesitate to replace it.

posts.com: is it worth it to change ball joints or should I just replace the whole control arms?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26239129
It really depends.
Just the ball joints will be cheaper, but you need a press, and you need to be 100% sure the ball joints are positioned correctly.
Most of the time, you'll also have to take the control arms out.
Myself, I find it easier to just replace the whole control arms, and start anew. Control arms aren't really expensive, but I guess it depends on the car.
Your call really. Just my 2 cents.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26238910
Where did you get it tested? The kids at the auto parts stores can be retarded.

But you could have a bad starter or a bad connection anywhere between the starter and battery as well. Time to break out the multimeter. The annoying thing is you’re not really going to be able to test resistance easily because resistance with a couple mA like the meter reads is different than starting the car with hundreds of amps. Maybe you can probe some different spots along the circuit while cranking the starter? I’m sure some Youtube genius knows more than me.

Either way you should have a multimeter. See what kind of voltage you get at the battery as you’re cranking the engine. HF also has 100A carbon pile load testers for cheap, and Amazon has the new Chinese digital ones for $25-$50, but a multimeter will test more than just the battery.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26242922
Might still be under warranty. Depending on your driving style, climate, and what grade of battery you got, 2-5 years is the general lifespan.

Load test it. The auto parts stores will do it too. That’s how you can tell if it’s on its way out. There are battery testers if you want to buy one too, or get yourself a multimeter and learn how to use it. The voltage of the battery is one thing, but a dying battery can still have good voltage when it’s just sitting there. But once you start cranking the starter, a good battery shouldn’t drop much more than 10V, a dead battery won’t start the car, and a dying battery will get like <9V when cranking the starter.
