posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26243421
It might just need a charge and a long drive. Lack of driving plus cold weather will lead to a low state of charge. But sounds like it’s on the edge. Lead acid batteries like being topped off all the time, so if you don’t drive much and your commutes are short, it’s not getting back up to 100% charge and will die faster than one in a car that takes more frequent long drives.

If you have a multimeter, look up how to test the battery and find a voltage drop test. Make sure the battery is somewhat charged like run the car for awhile the day or morning before, then all you need to do is measure the voltage as you’re starting the car and see how low it drops with the starter going. That will tell you a lot about the health.

posts.name: Bepis
posts.com:
>>26247600
Look at the CCA rating on your battery. If it’s a 600CCA battery in your car, go with some 800-1200A pack because the Chinaman lies. Add another 500 if you live somewhere cold.

I’m going to shill these Gooloo packs. That 1500 goes on sale on Amazon all the time for $60-$75, and I 100% recommend that. It will jump V8s with totally dead batteries no problem.

The cheap Gooloos that are black with the red power button, I have gotten 3 of those for family, they work well on everything up to V6s, but the charging circuit is outdated and a weak point, the newer 1500+ models use USB C and it’s less likely to fail.

Nocos are good and get shilled a lot, but you don’t get a lot of juice for the money. The standard 4cyl-6cyl pack is the GB40 which costs $100, and I have seen that fail to crank little 4cyl engines when the battery is real low. Would only shill NoCo if you need it for work or like life and death and you’re willing to drop $150+ on a larger model.

>>26248334
The real problem is people are retarded at following the market.

You always see shit like
>"man, an MR2 used to be like $2000!"

Yes, a clapped out, wrecked and poorly repaired 3 times MR2 with peeling paint and rod knock was $2000, but you saw the listing on craigslist with vague pictures taken at night with a digital camera from 1996 with a description that just said "come check it out" and didn't know what a piece of shit that car actually was.

Now, you see a well-kept MR2 for $15k and think it's overpriced, but the real difference is that one is actually worth owning and the $2000 one you saw in 2009 wasn't.

I've gone back and looked at forum posts from past time periods and car prices honestly stay pretty similar for equal condition after 10-15 years or so, sometimes even going down when factoring in inflation. People just suck at identifying cars of equal condition and are wondering why a collector-condition car costs so much when they saw a scrapheap for a low price 10 years ago.

There is a factor of people realizing that regulations are preventing many simple and unique cars from ever being made again, but that's far less of a driving force in the market than you think. You couldn't legally build a C4 Corvette for a laundry list of reasons today, but 90%+ of C4 owners would trade for a C8 in a heartbeat even if you forbid them from flipping it or selling it for more than the C4 was worth (no financial incentive, in other words). So those people weren't buying the car because they love old cars, they bought it because it was all the Corvette they could afford.

>>26250615
Do Gen 3s have issues beyond the engines in the early model years? Since if that's all, why not buy a toasted Gen 3 for cheap and do a Gen 4 engine swap?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26250651
The problem isn't necessarily with the engine itself, it's with the emissions system. In order to get even better emissions than the Gen 2, the Gen 3 has an EGR system along with an EGR cooler and (iirc) plastic lines. This system gets completely filled with shit every 60-85k miles, and sticks open. When this happens, you won't get a CEL, but it will blow the head gasket.

Doing a Gen 4 engine swap is costly and just not worth it (Pretty sure they use different cams and VVT system too). The Gen 3, ignoring th engine issues, isn't as well put together or as high quality as a Gen 2. And if you buy a decent looking Gen 3 with a blown engine, buy an engine, and swap it yourself or pay to swap it, you can just get a high mileage gen 4 for ~$10k, which would be the better car from a mechanical, interior, and quality perspective

Take the MSF, hopefully they have multiple different bikes to choose from, ask the instructor to try a few different ones out towards the end of the course.

Buy off FB Marketplace, try to bring someone that knows motorcycle mechanics with you (or arrange a mechanic inspection) to make sure you aren't buying a shitheap. Don't get a project bike to start, you need to start with a sorted bike so you know how it's supposed to ride and feel. Motorcycles are too dangerous to play with an improperly put together one. I would say a budget of $3000 could get you a solid Ninja 300 that will get you going.

>>26247238
>Who in the fuck puts that many unpalleted concrete bags on anything
Resolution sucks on that video, if you look at the bottom they are stacked in pallet sized towers. Looks like nine pallets.
Also note there are no straps. Pallets themselves are those newer plastic pallets, however some of those pallets have weight limits. Normally there would be a stack above the 5th wheel(hitch) and another stack above the rear axles. With a space in the middle, right about where the storage box is. Looks like someone stacked a bunch of wood pallets on top of the 5th wheel itself rather than weighted cargo.
Concrete bags weigh 94 bacon burgers(55Kilos) each.
6 bags/layer, 8 layers, which would be about 4,512 bacon burgers(2,640Kilos)/pallet.
IIRC typical wood pallets are only good enough for two and 1/4 Muricans or ~4500 bacon burgers each.
I have used some composite pallets that are rated for 10K kg, or 22,000 bacon burgers, or 11 Muricans.
There are light weight pallets that are used for transporting much lighter materisl, usually they have feet and can be stacked or 'nested' on top of each other, like legos to save space when not in use.
IIRC the average trailer can carry ~45,000 bacon burgers, or about 22 Muricans.
Looks like there are 9 pallets which would equate to about 40,000 bacon burgers, or 20 Muricans.
If all the above is correct then the trailer could have carried the load if it was loaded correctly.

But it looks like it was;
A. Loaded incorrectly without the weight over the 5th wheel nor over the rear axles or behind the rear axles to help cantilever.
B. Not secured(strapped) allowing the load to shift.
C. Lift axle was not lowered or failed(red hubbed leading trailer axle).

Albeit, trailer was loaded(incorrectly) and for whatever reason it was not strapped down before moving.
Driver goes down hill/brakes, rear load slides forward, front load too far back as is, combined weight of the load concentrates load in between axles and snaps the frame.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26247693
You're way underestimating the number of pallets here.

There may be some differences in difference in dimensions between the US and rest of world, and it's possible things have changed since I last needed to regularly haul cement, but here's my calculation--

A standard pallet of cement is 7 layers of 5 bags with each bag weighing 100 lbs / 45 kg for a total weight of 3500 lbs per pallet.

Pallet dimensions are 48"x40". With a fork lift, you can pick them up by the 40" side and load one each on the left and right sides of a flatbed. So, for every 10' of bed length, you can fit 6 pallets (3 pairs) or 21,000 lbs of cement.

That trailer looks about 50' long, so figure about 105k lbs if it were loaded with cement on pallets.

posts.sub: Cars are definitely getting worse, and it's easy to tell why
posts.com:
Think about it for a second:
When was the last time you heard someone saying "man, computers SUCK in 2023, things were so much better in the 90's when a computer was $5000 (in 1990's money) and to upgrade it you had to make fire hazard wiring and overheat every component and it would crash constantly. Then, a Windows update would brick a game and you had no way of getting a patch because the website stopped offering a download link."

No, computers have gotten better in every way: way more powerful, quieter, use less electricity (cheaper to run, fuck the EPA faggots), more modular and easier to upgrade, more reliable, more options, more stable OS that's easier to use, Steam and similar clients that make installs and updates game console-easy, etc.

Nobody is nostalgic for the shitty days of 90's and early 00's computers other than maybe remembering a LAN party they had with their friend or an old game they liked.

Now look at cars, everyone is constantly complaining about the new shit: new regs limiting body design, tons of emission parts that fuck up all the time, computers that are so complex even dealers can't figure them out, nannies that will intervene and stop you from doing things you want like back up with the door open to see better, iPad dash boards that are a tactile nightmare and offer nothing of value that a phone in a holder couldn't do, impossible to work on because everything requires a $5000 handheld to not have the car flip shit, crazy expensive even for low-tier models because they've gone so upmarket, etc. etc.

This is how we know we're not just being nostalgic hipsters, nobody is making these complaints about computers, it's not just getting older and reminiscing about the past, cars are legitimately going to shit and that's just what it is. So next time one of you faggots insist that new cars are actually better, go fucking kill yourself you disingenuous fuck.

Latency is the price you pay for security and flexibility. On a C64 you were writing characters/pixels directly to video RAM mapped to a physical screen location. The market has spoken, and that level of low latency is simply not what most people want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249964
I have tested a LOT of different bulbs and setups in my vehicles in recent years.

Even the very pricey OPT7 Fluxbeam led bulbs, which were OK on dry roads but just didn't cut it in the wet.

In my experience the problem with led bulbs is that their kelvin temperature (plus the light's wavelength probably) doesn't lend itself too well to on-road use.

The asphalt seems to absorb the light a LOT, especially on wet roads, and MUCH more so than with halogen or HID bulbs.

The absolute best light output on the road (no matter how many lumens the leds had) I've achieved in every test I've done, hands down came from a 55W 4300 kelvin HID bulb (that's Xenon for europoors). Any higher than 4300 kelvin and the light goes much too blue for real-world use.

The best part? Quality HIDs are much cheaper than (inferior) LEDs.

I spent a helluva lot of cash on bulbs and headlight kits and what have you before reaching the conclusion.

HID every time for me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26249964
Don't those come factory with projectors anyway? Just get a cheapo HID kit with harness for ~$30-40 and call it a day. Cheap harnesses can fail but I've had alright results with them over the years, but I've used the most dirt cheap xenon bulbs in my cars that come with them for years and they haven't burned out.
6k is about as high as you're going to want to go temperature wise for aesthetics, anything higher then that goes beyond new-car light territory and well into ricer/pulled over blue territory

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26244628

Injectors are messed up/misaligned on the cam or otherwise sticking when they're not supposed to. ECM tries to compensate by reducing power/disabling spark plugs for damage control. If you saw any leaks it was a cracked block and he was hiding it with copious amounts of block sealer, RTV and prayers. The last time that truck ran was when you parked it. Or maybe the engine mounts are just really fucked and the engine is literally shaking itself apart trying to spin into the frame.

If it was an actual crankshaft problem the engine wouldn't start in the first place. Though I wouldn't rule it out completely.. maybe no oil?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
To all the retards here:
1st things first. Car's a BMW 118d cabrio from 2010 I use to shit on civics.
Mods include air intake, intercooler, turbo, piping, exhaust, EGR and DPF delete and an aggressive remap. I did all the mods myself only took the car in for the remap and dyno testing.
Should output between 230 to 250hp though the clutch is OEM and it should be quite worn down now but I'll have it replaced with a 4 puck race one next month.

I have already done some troubleshooting, such as:
>MAF
Was my initial thought since it's been raining a lot and my high flow air filter can allow moisture to pass through at high speeds. Though it's dry now, I disconnected and checked sensor, all good. Scanner doesn't show now and never showed any MAF errors.
>Injectors
This is my 2nd set, they don't even have 50k on them. 4th injector showed an error on the scanner but it could just be clogged from unburnt diesel. I added 2 bottles of injector cleaner additive to the fuel and it's not giving out errors anymore.
>Vacuum lines
Was one of my thoughts considering the turbo pressure was fluctuating between 0 and 1 psi on idle Pressure should be constant unless there are leaks. However I did a smoke test and couldn't find anything sucking in.
>Glow plugs
Last culprit. 2 of them show up faults on the scanner. It is definitely the reason for the hard starting when cold. Could be the reason for rough idling and hiccups at lower rpms. If the chamber doesn't heat up correctly, there could be misfires and fuel not being burnt properly, especially when I have the car remapped and there's nore fuel being injected. It explains why it hiccups at low rpms, when the turbo isn't building enough pressure and the ecu compensates with more fuel than it can be burnt.
>EGR valve
It's deleted so it can't be that

In the end I think it's the glow plugs. Retards at the shop told me they were fine even though they show up faults and one of them has a broken head and feels somewhat loose.

Ok /o/ I'm fully prepared to be called a retard in this thread but it's ok because I need the advice regardless

I bought 96 toyota celica (I do not watch scotty) a few years ago and a few months after it needed a new clutch kit installed. I just chalked this up to it being an old car and the clutch already felt kinda wobbly initially so this wasn't a huge surprise for me.

Car gave me essentially no issues for about 1.5 years when suddenly last month the clutch started slipping really badly again. Within the course of just a few weeks it got so bad that it literally couldn't move anymore on the very day I was gonna take it to the mechanic. I had to get it towed there and of course they told me the clutch is fucked and needs replaced.

I have the money to fix it again no problem but what the fuck am I doing wrong to have fucked the clutch up again? I don't think it's normal for a clutch to get fucked that badly in less than 2 years unless my previous mechanic somehow fucked something up really bad, or if I just suck at driving a manual. I'm pretty new to driving stick and this car is the first manual I've owned, I had my dad teach me how to drive it and I asked him if I'm doing anything incorrectly last time I drove his car (also a stick) and he said I was fine. Is there any common errors I might be overlooking when driving manual that could've led to the clutch getting fucked again so soon? I definitely don't want to have this issue again especially for something that might be my fault

>>26249945
Your clutch fluid system may have been weak and the clutch was experiencing slip and slowly over time it wore out again. You should take a look at the clutch master/slave cylinder and see if you're getting the proper application. What about the diaphragm spring? Does that still have good tension.

>t. recently got license

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>26250024

if you arent planning on moving for >10sec, pop it in Neutral

read the cars ahead of you, keep your RPMs within range for 1st when goin slow

clutch lifespan is affected by friction/erosion and wear from disconnecting and connecting the crankshaft and drivetrain.

as long as you are not stalling or engaging at wierd gear combos (think anything that would place load on the friction plate)

the master and slave cylinders transmit your foot actuation to the pressure plate/friction disc/flywheel if one goes out, you get incomplete diconnects ie rubbing, and once worn down enough, slippage

posts.name: dead

>>26249363

I would hesitate to by an automatic one but with a manual transmission that will just keep on going. just don't buy something that old if you live in the rust belt or area where they use road salt. the only reason E100 corollas have disappeared from some areas is because of the rust. people in africa keep rocking these things virtually forever

I remember working in car sales and we would get these shitboxes as trade ins. their practical value was zero, many of them belonged to a scrap yard but some of them had, legally or not so legally, a valid inspection for anywhere from 6 to 12 months, making it a valid buy for someone who just needs some shitbox for the season. so if it was a volkswagen or something like an opel, a shit car basically, we would take it as a trade in and value at $500 but really it was more like we took in the car, gave the buyer a $500 discount off his new car and then tried to get rid of the shitty opel we just got handed. most ended up at the scrapper for +/- $0 but at least not our problem

BUT if it was a toyota of any form, no matter the rust, if you could start it and sometimes even if you couldn't, you took one in as a trade in, wash it and put it online at 3pm. by 4pm several africans would call or leave voice messages and come morning the next day the toyota would be gone and by dusk the car is already probably in some container on its way to africa. I spoke to one of the africans who do this, I asked them how can they make a worthless car like this worth shipping to africa, but the dude said they are premium cars there, they can fix the rust damage and it doesn't rust more in africa. he pays anywhere from $500 to 1000 for the car, shipping and bribing to get it in the country he's $2000 out of pocket and he sells them for $3000+ after some kids wash it and fix the problems since wages in africa are next to nothing

he was just one of the dozen who do this. they were nice, good-ish english, cash in hand, car gone stat

>>26249870
To prevent overheating and brake fade on high demand applications like going down a mountain, you want to apply the brakes harder, slow down to like 5mph under your “safe speed”, and then let go of the brakes and coast back up to that speed, hit brakes again and repeat.

posts.sub: Consumer Reports Says Subaru Makes The Best Vehicles, Jeep The Worst
posts.com:
Consumer Reports has released their latest Brand Report Card, which saw Japanese and German automakers come out on top.

Subaru was named the best brand, with an overall score of 81. It was followed by Mazda and BMW, which each had a score of 78. Honda and Lexus were close behind with scores of 77, followed by Audi (75), Porsche (74), MINI, (74), Toyota (74), and Infiniti (72).

American brands had a lackluster showing as Buick came in 11th place with an overall score of 72. It was followed by Chrysler (71), Dodge (67), Cadillac (63), and Ford (62).

Tesla came in 23rd place with an overall score of 60 which was the same as Chevrolet and Mercedes. Tesla dropped seven spots and Consumer Reports said this was “mainly due to the difficult-to-use yoke steering wheel” that was recently introduced on the Model S and Model X.

Jeep came in last place with an overall score of 45. The publication didn’t say much about this but cited “reliability issues” with the Gladiator. Other low performers were Alfa Romeo (50), Land Rover (49), Mitsubishi (49), and GMC (48).

>Taking a turn a little wide isn’t all that uncommon when space allows for it but as Foster pointed out, it is actually illegal in many places. Cruise released its own statement surrounding the issue with a plan of action and a promise.
>“Safety is Cruise’s top priority, not just for our passengers but for everyone we share the road with.
